citation.article-title: Marinimicrobium locisalis sp. nov., isolated from a marine solar saltern, and emended description of the genus Marinimicrobium
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Marinimicrobium locisalis sp. nov.
Marinimicrobium locisalis (lo.ci.sa′lis. L. n. locus place, locality; L. gen. n. salis of salt; N.L. gen. n. locisalis from a place of salt).
Cells are Gram-negative and non-spore-forming rods, 0.2–0.4×0.7–3.5 μm.
Motile by means of a single polar flagellum.
Colonies on MA are circular to irregular, raised to slightly convex, glistening, smooth, yellow-green and 1.0–1.5 mm in diameter after incubation at 30 °C for 5 days.
Growth occurs at 4 and 40 °C, but not at 45 °C, and at pH 6.0, but not at pH 5.5 (optimum pH 7.0–8.0).
Growth occurs in the presence of 18 % (w/v) NaCl, but not without NaCl or with more than 19 % (w/v) NaCl.
Optimum growth occurs in the presence of approximately 2 % (w/v) NaCl.
Anaerobic growth does not occur on MA or on MA supplemented with nitrate.
Tweens 40 and 60 are hydrolysed, but hypoxanthine is not.

l-Arabinose, cellobiose, d-glucose, maltose, d-xylose and salicin are utilized, but d-fructose, d-galactose, d-mannose, trehalose, sucrose, acetate, citrate, succinate, benzoate, l-malate, pyruvate, formate and l-glutamate are not.
Acid is produced from cellobiose and d-galactose, but not from melezitose, l-rhamnose or d-sorbitol.

Susceptible to ampicillin, carbenicillin, cephalothin, chloramphenicol, gentamicin, neomycin, polymyxin B, oleandomycin and streptomycin, but not to kanamycin, lincomycin, novobiocin, penicillin G or tetracycline.
The major fatty acids (>10 % of total fatty acids) are C16 : 0, C19 : 0ω8c, C16 : 1ω7c and/or iso-C15 : 0 2-OH, and C18 : 1ω7c.
Other phenotypic characteristics are given in Table 1.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 58.4 mol%.
The type strain, ISL-43T (=KCTC 22484T=CCUG 56757T), was isolated from a marine solar saltern of the Yellow Sea, Korea.
